Walking a fine line here, obviously - as is ""Parasite,"" a satire from Korea about class warfare, and ""Greener Grass,"" a Sundance hit that shreds suburban cliches.
These are chilly comedies.

I'm Bob Mondello.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
(Soundbite of trumpet and rattle)
Whoo!
Hey, it sounds like we're having a party.
Maybe we are.
We're celebrating because Ted has turned one.
Ted is the Ted Spread.
It's an economic indicator at the heart of this global credit crisis.
And the Ted Spread shot up in October to over four, had a rough November, but it's come down from those rocky heights.
NPR's David Kestenbaum is here now.
You're really having a party?
Yeah.
(Soundbite of trumpet)
Woohoo.
(Soundbite of rattle)
Sounds like Eeyore's having a birthday party.
Yeah.
It's just me here.
(Soundbite of laughter)
It's kind of anemic.
(Soundbite of laughter)
It's the best I can do.
And things are looking up a little bit.
So tell us about the Ted Spread.
Why is it so important?
It is actually the key thing to watch.
A woman at Treasury told me, basically, it is what she watches to see how things are going.
It measures how willing big banks are to lend to each other.
And you know nothing is right in the world when big banks won't lend to each other.
It's just such a bad sign.
I mean, this is what we were talking about, you know, in the credit crunch.
This is at the heart of it.
So at the peak of the crisis, banks were not willing to lend to each other.
They were worried the bank around the corner might collapse and not pay them back, or they were worried about their own health.
So now they are more willing to lend.
And we always tell people, I know the stock market's upsetting.
Don't look at that.
Look at the Ted Spread.
So you want Ted to be low?
We want Ted to be low, yeah.
